subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Quickscript Unicode Proposal

messageBody:
Hi Paige, no offense was taken at all, I hope it didn't seem so.

(In re-reading this before sending, it appears I am repeating some of what Joseph just said.  Just a bit more long-winded.)

(And in re-re-reading this after sending it the first time, it looks like the Yahoo editor has once again mangled my post.  Let me try to re-send through a real email client.)

Let me explain a little more what I mean about 'avoiding separate glyphs for diphthongs.' I think I did not describe it well before, and it actually relates quite a bit to your other item on a half-ye.  (I agree, btw, that a half-ye is a good addition).  Given its design, a given letter in Quickscript can have several different forms.  Many of the tall letters, as you point out, can be written as half-letters, top only, and some of the deep letters can also be written bottom only.  Likewise, many letters can be combined to a greater extent.  The 'standard' ligatures in the Quickscript manual, you and air and the like, are really two separate letters that are drawn together.

I am sure you all know this, I don't mean to be pedantic.  However, when Shavian was put into Unicode, for some reason several of these combined letters were included in the encoding.  Specifically, encodings 10477 through 1047F: are (a combination of ah and roar), or (awe and roar), air, err, array, ear, ian, and yew.  According to the Unicode proposals page (http://www.unicode.org/pending/proposals.html), "Often a proposed character can be expressed as a sequence of one or more existing Unicode characters. Encoding the proposed character would be a duplicate representation, and is thus not suitable for encoding."  I would argue that these combined character representation are just that, sequences of one or more existing characters (from the rest of the Shavian encoding block).

I think my original message was a misstatement in two ways: I misused the word "diphthong," which really means combined vowels, to mean combines sequences of letters.  (Shavian and Quickscript both code several diphthongs as single characters, which is reasonable given their prevalence in English.)  Secondly, I misused the word "glyph," which in Unicode parlance means "a way of drawing a character or sequence of characters."  In fact, we should have multiple glyphs for the tall tea and the half-tea, but both glyphs should represent the same encoding.  The Wikipedia entry on Unicode (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unicode) set me straight on this terminology.

Here is where my own knowledge of Unicode and font rendering systems fails.  The proposal page mentioned above also says "If the proposed characters exhibit shaping behavior (contextual shaping, ligatures, conjuncts, or stacking), provide a description of that behavior,  preferably with glyph examples. It should be sufficient so that software engineers can produce a minimally acceptable rendering of the characters."  This seems to indicate to me that there can be multiple representations for a single encoding: multiple glyphs per character.  Indeed, the "Where is my Character?" page on the Unicode site (http://www.unicode.org/standard/where/) makes this very clear.  See "variant shapes."

What does this all mean?  Well, one effect of only having a single encoding per letter will be that, at first, each character will only have one single form and thus the fonts will probably look like Junior Quickscript rather than Senior.  However, as Quickscript becomes more accepted and popular, font designers will be able to create more complex fonts which are able to combine sequences of characters into something more closely representing Senior Quickscript.  But when that happens, older texts (i.e., those encoded in Unicode, but before the complex fonts were created) will not have to be re-encoded, because the only thing that will change is how the characters are represented.  See the "Ready-made versus composite characters" section of the Wikipedia article, above.

Edward brings up a good suggestion of using the ConScript Unicode Registry as a test-bed for Quickscript encoding.  I have looked at it before, and am hesitant only because it appears to not have been updated in recent years.  However, Michael Everson is known to have gotten several alternate scripts (including Shavian) into the Unicode standard, and some of those started in the ConScript registry.

If someone wants to take a stab at it, perhaps we can move forward with converting an existing Quickscript font to Unicode within the Conscript block.  I propose using the character range U+E650 through U+E67F, which follows immediately after the "Seussian Latin Extensions" range in the ConScript (http://www.evertype.com/standards/csur/seuss.html).  To convert an existing font, one may wish to try the tool FontForge (http://fontforge.sourceforge.net/).  It is an excellent free font editing tool which (with a little bit of work) can be installed on Windows (requires cygwin), Mac OS X (requires X11), or Linux.  I should point out that some characters in these fonts should NOT be moved to new locations.  All numbers and punctuation should be left where they are, as they are already in their correct Unicode placement.  Only the letters (in the QS Unicode proposal) should be moved; and the ligatures can be removed entirely.  Once we have an example font in place, we can register it with the conscript (though exactly how I am not sure), and also start the 'real' Unicode proposal process.  In the meantime, we will be able to start playing with mixed Quickscript/standard orthography messages.

I will try to do the font editing exercise myself... but not tonight.  My wife is already giving me the evil eye to get off of the damned machine.

oliver
